chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
text:
The  Government  of  The  Bahamas  is  committed  to  advancing  climate  resilience, 
sustainability, gender inclusion, and institutional capacity within the aviation sector. To 
achieve this, the TC will support the development of a comprehensive Sustainable and 
Inclusive Aviation Strategy for The Bahamas that will establish a framework for green, 
low carbon, climate change resilient, and energy efficient and inclusive aerodromes. 
Moreover, the strategy will aim to promote gender equity through grants for women in 
aviation, enhance opportunities for persons with disabilities PwDs in aviation careers, 
and  expand  aviation  cadet  training  programs  to  engage  and  prepare  the  next 
generation of industry professionals. Additionally, the strategy will explore pathways 
for integrating sustainable aviation fuels, aligning with global efforts to reduce carbon 
emissions in the sector.

chunk_title: Description of the Associated Loan, BH-L1041
text:
The  ongoing  airport  infrastructure  program  includes  two  components,  i)  Civil  Works 
and  Equipment,  and  ii)  Implementation  Support  and  Institutional  Strengthening, 
Component  one  finances  investments  needed  to  upgrade  the  infrastructure  and 
equipment of the four selected Family Island airports. To meet projected traffic, comply 
with International Civil Aviation (ICAO) standards, and increase the climate resilience 
of the airports, the component includes the upgrading and rehabilitation of the airport 
runways,  taxiways,  parking  aprons  and  meteorological  equipment,  runway  lights, 
markings, and fencing. It also incorporates terminal works to equip the airports with 
infrastructure  capable  of  handling  increasing  passengers  while  providing  energy 
efficiency  and  climate  resilience.  Equipment  also  includes  Rescue  and  Firefighting 
(RFF) vehicles and X-ray machines for passenger terminals.

chunk_title: Objective of the TC
text: The primary aim of this Technical Cooperation (TC) is to enhance resiliency and biodiversity in Latin American and Caribbean (LAC) cities by integrating green solutions into urban design. The specific objectives are (i) build a comprehensive knowledge base on climate vulnerability and resilience; (ii) develop innovative solutions through pilot projects; and (iii) increase visibility of nature-based solutions and strengthen capacities.

chunk_title: Executing Agency, Risks and ESPF Alignment
text: V. Executing Agency and Execution Structure. At the request of the Government of the Dominican Republic, the Bank, through the Water and Sanitation Division (WSA), in collaboration with the Climate Change Division (CCS), will be responsible for implementing this TC by contracting consultancies to carry out the planned activities. The Bank will identify the necessary studies and technical work, select and hire consultants, and manage the execution and delivery of consultancy services following its established procurement procedures. The execution mechanism is justified because WSA, CCS and the IDB have substantial experience providing technical assistance in areas such as sanitation and water remediation, climate-friendly infrastructure, nature-based solutions, low-carbon technology, and implementation of nationally determined contributions. VI. Project Risks and Issues. Key risks include extreme natural phenomena such as hurricanes or severe storms that could damage or destroy restored corals or related infrastructure; lack of continuity in funding that could disrupt restoration and monitoring activities; challenges in inter-institutional coordination among public, private and NGO entities; and operational risks during pilot execution that could affect the effectiveness of the financing and restoration mechanism. Mitigation measures involve contingency actions, diversified and mandatory fundraising, clear governance and coordination frameworks, and detailed planning and monitoring of the pilot phase with flexibility for adjustments. VII. Environmental and Social Aspects. This TC does not have applicable requirements under the Bank’s Environmental and Social Policy Framework (ESPF).

chunk_title: Major Risks, Mitigation and Environmental/Social Aspects
text: The TC faces risks related to potential changes in subnational administrations, which may affect continuity and prioritization, as well as challenges in coordinating institutions responsible for subnational financing and technical capacity limitations. To mitigate these risks, the Bank’s role as executor is a key risk management strategy, complemented by regular training sessions and periodic meetings with relevant subnational officials, early and frequent stakeholder engagement, and collaboration with technical experts. There is also a risk regarding the sustainability of the platform and program once IDB funding ends, which will be mitigated by robust governance mechanisms, city leadership, long-term partnerships with organizations such as C40 and CCFLA, and efforts to attract external funding from climate funds, grants, and donors. The TC will finance diagnostics, policy dialogues, capacity building, and feasibility studies for investment projects and associated environmental and social studies, all of which will be consistent with the applicable requirements of the Bank’s Environmental and Social Policy Framework (ESPF).

chunk_title: Component 2 – Creditworthiness and Investment Management Assessment
text: Component 2, “Assessment of creditworthiness and investment management capacities of selected SNGs or their entities” (US$250,000), aims to prepare financially selected cities and SNGs for operations without sovereign guarantees. It will finance: (i) the development of a creditworthiness analysis methodology to assess the technical and financial readiness of SNGs or their entities for subnational finance, including evaluation of legal frameworks and borrowing readiness; (ii) the implementation of this methodology in selected SNGs or their entities to evaluate their creditworthiness, investment management, and urban governance capacities through in-depth diagnostics of fiscal capacity, financial management, public administration, planning, and investment capabilities; and (iii) the development and initial implementation of a plan of fiscal reforms to improve subnational creditworthiness based on the analysis.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Coral Restoration Challenges and Link to Sanitation Program
text: 2.2 Coral restoration in the Dominican Republic faces significant challenges due to the lack of a sustainable financing system that ensures continuity and scaling of existing efforts. Current initiatives, though valuable, are temporary and fragmented, limiting their impact on biodiversity protection and the resilience of marine ecosystems. The absence of an integrated and long-term approach hinders the response to the accelerated loss of reefs. Therefore, this TC focuses on designing a technical and financial mechanism that structures and enhances available resources, ensuring restoration actions are sustainable, scalable, and effective in protecting natural capital and fostering coastal economic development. The activities financed by this TC complement and enhance the expected impact of the Program DR-L1165 (Universal Sanitation Program in Coastal and Tourist Cities of the Dominican Republic II), whose main objective is to improve access to quality sanitation services in coastal and tourist cities, prioritizing environmental sustainability and climate resilience. The program allocates US$1.5 million for coral reef recovery, recognizing their crucial role in coastal protection and biodiversity. Additional resources from this TC will be mobilized to design and implement a sustainable technical and financial mechanism, ensuring the continuity and scalability of coral restoration efforts. These resources accelerate the strategic actions of DR-L1165, integrating nature-based solutions with large infrastructure investments and reinforcing natural capital conservation and the resilience of coastal communities to the effects of climate change.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – Importance of the Amazon Basin
text: 2.2 The Amazon basin hosts the world’s largest tropical rainforest, making it a global center of biological diversity. As the largest hydrographic basin in the world, it produces nearly 20% of the planet's freshwater and contains 25% of the world's terrestrial biodiversity. In South America, it represents 70% of the freshwater discharge, playing a vital role in regulating climate patterns, sustaining ecosystems, ensuring water, food and energy security, and supporting the livelihoods of local communities. Furthermore, the Amazon is crucial to climate resilience as it naturally sequesters approximately 150–200 billion tons of carbon dioxide in soils and vegetation, functioning as one of the planet’s largest carbon sinks.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
text: The aviation sector is critical to regional integration in The Bahamas. An archipelagic country, consisting of 700 islands spread over 100,000 square miles of ocean, the population of over 400,000 is primarily (70.4%) concentrated on the island of New Providence, while approximately 15% of residents are located on Grand Bahama, with the remainder of the population spread across the other 28 Family Islands. Moreover, the remoteness of the Family Islands (FI) and their long distances to the major population centers means local Bahamians residing outside of New Providence and Grand Bahama are highly dependent on accessible, reliable and frequent modes of air transport for both domestic and international travel.

chunk_title: Evaluation Design and Methodology (DID)
text: 2.3 The evaluation plans to adopt a staggered difference-in-differences (DID) design that leverages the phased rollout of Vida Nova across communities. Beneficiary families will receive the new housing and social services at different times, creating variations that can be exploited for causal identification. This DID approach allows the evaluation to control for common time trends while estimating the program’s impact, using later-treated groups as controls for the early-treated groups. Under the assumption of parallel trends of potential outcomes between treated and not-yet-treated, this method allows for estimation of causal effects.

chunk_title: Objectives and Justification of the TC
text:
Climate  Change:  International  aviation  currently  contributes  approximately  2.5%  of 
global CO₂ emissions, up from 2.3% in 2000, and this share is expected to rise due to 
the continued expansion of air transport worldwide2. Recognizing the sector’s growing 
environmental impact, the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), has 
adopted  a  set  of  global  aspirational  goals  aimed  at  mitigating  aviation’s  carbon 
footprint. These include a 2% annual improvement in fuel efficiency and a commitment 
to  cap  net  carbon  emissions  at  2020  levels,  despite  projected  growth  in  air  traffic. 
These targets underscore the urgent need for countries like The Bahamas, which are 
highly vulnerable to climate change and heavily reliant on aviation for connectivity and 
economic development, to pursue sustainable, inclusive, and climate-resilient aviation 
strategies.

chunk_title: MDB Reform Agenda and IDB Subnational Strategy
text: Recommendations from the G20 and other expert groups have been advocating for reforms in multilateral development banks (MDBs) to facilitate subnational access to climate finance, and other international organizations such as C40 and the Cities Climate Finance Leadership Alliance have made similar requests. International financial institutions have already increased sub-sovereign lending in LAC. In this context, the IDB’s Institutional Strategy highlights the exploration of legal and technical viability and potential demand for mechanisms to support subnational governments and state-owned enterprises in improving local finances, creating bankable projects and ultimately creditworthiness. The IDB has started to develop a new Subnational Government Program to provide selected SNGs and their entities with direct access to finance without sovereign guarantees, while helping them build the necessary capacities to take on debt and prepare pipelines of projects contributing to social and climate goals.

chunk_title: Emerging Demand and Climate Finance Gap
text: The infrastructure gap in LAC is large and growing. The IDB estimates that the region will need substantial investments in the water and sanitation, energy, transport, and telecommunication sectors by 2030 to advance commitments towards the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), requiring more than a 70% increase in infrastructure investment by 2030. SNGs are responsible for over a third of public investment in crucial services and are at the forefront of actions to mitigate and adapt to climate change. However, global urban climate finance is far below what is needed, with less than 10% of overall climate finance directed toward cities. While much of this investment occurs at the national level, there is a growing demand for climate finance among creditworthy SNGs and their state-owned enterprises in LAC, which are looking to upgrade existing infrastructure and invest in new infrastructure to meet growing demand sustainably.

chunk_title: Fiscal Advances, Creditworthiness and Access to Finance
text: Fiscal responsibility frameworks in LAC have contributed to increased budgetary sustainability, but cities and SNGs still need to improve their creditworthiness to invest more and with better quality. This includes strengthening their capacities to raise revenue, handle budgets, manage projects, and access financing in an efficient, transparent, and fiscally sustainable manner. Creditworthiness also depends on intergovernmental arrangements that define how fiscal responsibilities, own taxes, transfers, and access to debt are allocated between levels of government, supported by technical assistance programs. Although cities’ access to finance can help reduce social and infrastructure gaps, only a small share of large cities in developing countries have access to international or even domestic financing markets. In LAC, subnational financing averages less than 3% of GDP, compared to 12% in OECD countries, due to weaknesses in fiscal relations, limited capacity to access credit markets, and a history of bailouts.

chunk_title: Component 1 – Design of the Subnational Pilot Program Proposal
text: Component 1, “Support in the design of the Subnational Pilot Program Proposal” (US$150,000), aims to assist the development of the IDB’s Subnational Lending Program proposal by supporting the inter-departmental working group in designing the SNGs financing mechanism, the sub-sovereign pre-investment facility, and the first operations without sovereign guarantee. It will finance: (i) the assessment and analysis of background information, documents, and lessons learned from IDB and other international financial institutions to design a new operational mechanism for loans to SNGs without sovereign guarantees; (ii) the development of a benchmark analysis to identify resources for reimbursable or non-reimbursable technical cooperation to work with SNGs; and (iii) recommendations on critical elements for formulating the first subnational operations without sovereign guarantee.

chunk_title: Executing Agency and Execution Structure
text: V. Executing Agency and Execution Structure. 5.1 This Technical Cooperation (TC) will be executed by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), at the request of the Government of the Dominican Republic, in order to ensure the timely and high-quality preparation of two strategic and technically complex operations. Execution by the Bank is justified given the early design stage of both operations, which require a high degree of technical coordination, compliance with environmental and fiduciary standards, and the mobilization of specialized expertise. The IDB has substantial experience in providing technical assistance for the preparation of water and sanitation programs across the region, including the promotion of wastewater reuse in tourism-intensive and water-scarce areas, the design of public-private participation schemes, and the preparation of performance-based contracts such as those based on FIDIC standards. The Bank has also supported the incorporation of climate resilience and aquifer protection measures into water security programs in several countries. This accumulated experience will be applied to ensure the delivery of high-quality studies and technical inputs aligned with the objectives and scope of both operations. The TC will be executed by the Water and Sanitation Division (INE/WSA) in coordination with the IDB Country Office in the Dominican Republic. 5.2 The TC will be executed by the Bank through the hiring of consultancies to carry out the planned activities. In close dialogue with the public and private sectors, as well as other non-governmental institutions with technical capabilities and experience in the Dominican Republic, the Bank will be responsible for (i) identifying the necessary studies and technical work; (ii) selecting and hiring consultants to provide the necessary services; and (iii) managing the execution and delivery of the consulting services. All procurements to be executed under this TC will be contracted in accordance with the Bank's applicable policies and regulations.

chunk_title: Executing Agency, Execution Structure, Risks and ESPF Alignment
text:
V. Executing Agency and Execution Structure
5.1 Due to federal budgetary reasons in the country the TC will be executed by the Bank, through the Water and Sanitation Division (WSA). The Terms of Reference for the activities will be finalized in coordination with the sector institutions (water, sanitation and solid waste operators, SEMARNAT, CONAGUA, and/or ANEAS). 5.2 All procurement to be executed under this TC will be hired in compliance with the applicable Bank policies and regulations as follows: (a) Hiring of individual consultants, as established in the regulation on Complementary Workforce (AM-650) and (b) Contracting of services provided by consulting firms and non-consulting services in accordance with the Corporate procurement Policy (GN-2303-33) and its Guidelines. Monitoring and Evaluation. The execution monitoring will be carried out through the following mechanisms: (i) technical working meetings between the water and sanitation IDB's team in Mexico and the consultants; (ii) IDB’s review (and eventually the beneficiaries’ entities) of the technical reports to be presented by the consultants; and (iii) coordination meetings. From the date of the signing of the first consultancy contract, at the end of each year, and after the closing date, the IDB team will address all relevant CT reporting and evaluation requirements, including at least: (i) description of progress; (ii) relevant technical aspects to highlight; and (iii) execution problems and pending issues.
VI. Project Risks and Issues
6.1 The major risk during the execution of this TC is the potential delay in execution of the consulting services due to a lack of coordination between the Bank, as the Executing Agency, and Mexican sector institutions. To mitigate this risk, the Bank’s team will maintain regular meetings with such institutions. WSA has significant experience executing TCs in the water, sanitation and solid waste sector that requires close coordination with the counterparts, and the division has very solid capacity locally in the Country Office of Mexico.
VII. Environmental and Social Aspects
7.1 This Technical Cooperation is intended to finance pre-feasibility or feasibility studies of specific investment projects and the environmental and social studies associated with them; therefore, the terms of reference and products of this TC will be consistent with the applicable requirements of the Bank’s Environmental and Social Policy Framework (ESPF).

chunk_title: Justification – Urbanization, SNGs and Infrastructure Gaps
text: Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) has over 17,000 subnational governments (SNGs) and is highly urbanized, with roughly 81% of its population living in cities, the most significant proportion of any region globally. This urbanization underscores the potential of these areas to enhance productivity and innovation. Additionally, SNGs are at the forefront of actions to mitigate and adapt to climate change. Around 300 of these cities have populations exceeding 500,000 inhabitants and exhibit signs of creditworthiness, with roughly 10% having established credit ratings. SNGs in LAC are responsible for over a third of public investment in the region, yet the region is the second lowest globally in terms of infrastructure spending and infrastructure quality tends to deteriorate further at the subnational level. Expanding IDB’s programs to support and lend directly to SNGs provides an opportunity to diversify its lending portfolio, expand its client base, and help achieve decentralization goals.

chunk_title: Objective and Justification – General Objective
text: 2.1 The general objective of this TC is to promote the development, integration and scaling of innovative solutions in the water, sanitation and solid waste sector, which contribute to the achievement of universal access to quality water, sanitation and solid waste services, managed in an efficient manner, safely, sustainable and resilient. The specific objectives are (i) to promote the agenda of innovation and to foster alliances between actors; (ii) strengthen demand for innovative solutions; (iii) identify and support current and future loan operations.
